docs.lead_paragraph: MICROSOFT AND LINUX -- Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system by striking an agreement with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell's version of Linux can operate together with Windows. [Page C1.] CRUISE TO HELP LEAD UNITED ARTISTS -- Tom Cruise, the film star who took a beating when Paramount ended his longstanding production deal last summer, has found not just a home, but a new career direction that could point the way for expensive actors who are struggling in cost-conscious Hollywood. Mr. Cruise and his producing partner, Paula Wagner, will take charge of United Artists, the production company started by Charlie Chaplin and Mary Pickford. [C1.] NEW MEDICAID POLICY -- Under a new federal policy, children born in the United States to illegal immigrants with low incomes will no longer be automatically entitled to health insurance through Medicaid, Bush administration officials said. [A1.] DISAPPOINTING RETAIL SALES -- Wal-Mart Stores was one of several large retailers, along with Target and CostCo, to post disappointing October sales totals. [C1.] UTILITY SWITCH -- On Tuesday, voters in Yolo County in California will decide whether residents will switch from Pacific Gas and Electric to the municipal utility. Supporters of the change say it will lower costs. Opponents, including P.G.&E., are afraid it will set a bad precedent. [C1.] HOME OWNERSHIP AD CAMPAIGN -- The National Association of Realtors will begin promoting the notion that buying a home is an unalloyed good in a $40 million campaign that boldly declares: ''It's a great time to buy or sell a home.'' Advertising. [C7.] EX-CHIEF SENTENCED TO 12 YEARS -- The former chief executive of Computer Associates International, Sanjay Kumar, was sentenced yesterday to 12 years in prison for orchestrating a $2.2 billion accounting fraud at the software company. He was also fined $8 million. [C3.] HINT IN EUROPE ON RATES -- The European Central Bank signaled that it would raise its benchmark interest rate for the sixth time in a year when it meets in December, as it tries to curb inflation in an expanding European economy. [C5.] RUSSIA PRESSURES GEORGIA ON OIL -- Russia intensified its economic pressure on Georgia as the state-controlled gas monopoly, Gazprom, indicated that it would seek to more than double the price it charges for natural gas, beginning in January. [A12.] ARRESTS IN ONLINE THEFTS -- At least three Americans and 11 Polish nationals have been arrested in the last month in a crackdown on an online black market in which users buy and sell credit card numbers, bank account log-ins and other information, federal investigators say. [C4.] RUNWAY ERRORS NOT UNCOMMON -- Using the wrong runway, the error that led to the crash in Kentucky that killed 49 people in August, is not so rare, a top official of the Federal Aviation Administration said at a safety conference. [A21.] INSTINET IS SOLD -- Less than a year after buying Instinet, the electronic brokerage firm, the private equity firm Silver Lake Partners has agreed to sell the company. [C3.] LOWER INCOME AT CBS -- CBS reported lower net income from a year ago, when it was still combined with Viacom, but operating earnings rose. The company also announced a share buyback of up to $1.5 billion. Investors have been pressing CBS to say what its plans are for its growing cash stockpile, which is at $3.2 billion. [C4.] JANITORS STRIKE IN HOUSTON -- More than 5,000 janitors have gone on strike because five Houston cleaning companies have rejected their proposal for a salary increase to $8.50 an hour, up from the current average of $5.25 an hour. [A18.] CHINA AND AFRICA -- China is courting Africa with both economic and political goals in mind. Its economic goal is to secure Africa's abundant supplies of oil, iron ore, copper and cotton at the lowest possible prices, analysts say. [A1.] STOCKS FALL -- Stocks continued to decline, dipping lower after the Labor Department said productivity was flat in the third quarter while wages rose nearly 4 percent. The data raised concerns that the Federal Reserve would continue to wrestle with inflation, possibly raising interest rates again. [C7.]
docs.snippet: MICROSOFT AND LINUX -- Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system by striking an agreement with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell's version of Linux can operate together with Windows. [Page C1.]    CRUISE TO HELP...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Federal Web Site Offers Clues to Build Atom Bomb The federal government set up a Web site to make public a vast archive of Iraqi documents captured during the war. But some of the documents posted, weapons experts say, are themselves a danger, including some that may constitute a basic guide to building an atom bomb. A1 Tucked away in a huge military authorization bill signed by President Bush is what some of Stuart W. Bowen Jr.'s supporters believe is his reward for embarrassing the administration with investigations into reconstruction money spent in Iraq: a pink slip, in the form of an obscure provision terminating the federal oversight agency that he heads. A1 China Continues to Court Africa Beijing has put on its best face to court Africa as political leaders of 48 of the 53 African countries are to arrive in Beijing this weekend for a huge diplomatic event. A1 Delayed Thai Democracy Six weeks after a bloodless coup in Thailand, the mess of politics has reasserted itself and the generals are fumbling a bit with their new image as managers. Complaints have begun that these fix-it men have not produced ''instant democracy.'' A3 South African AIDS Fight Departing from years of indecision and, on occasion, denial, South Africa's government is considering a new and sweeping assault on an AIDS pandemic that already includes one in eight of the world's H.I.V. infections. A4 NATIONAL A18-25 Candidates Struggle to Win Women's Votes in Virginia In Virginia, Senator George Allen, a Republican, and Jim Webb, a Democrat, are locked in an exceedingly tight contest, one of a handful that will determine control of the Senate. But the real struggle may be about winning the votes of women. A1 In what Democrats have worked hard to portray as a ''culture of corruption'' in the Republican Party, more than a dozen Republicans in House races have wrestled with the taint of a Congressional page scandal and links to Jack Abramoff. Still, there are Democrats whose campaigns have also been marked by claims of ethical failings. A23 New Medicaid Rules Announced Under a new federal policy, children born in the United States to undocumented immigrants with low incomes will no longer be automatically entitled to health insurance through Medicaid, Bush administration officials said. A1 War Crime Trials to Begin The Pentagon expects to begin conducting the first war crimes trials at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, under the new military commission law by summer, senior military officials have said. A18 Dire Warning on Fishing If fishing around the world continues at its present pace, more species will vanish, marine ecosystems will unravel and there will be ''global collapse'' of all species currently fished, possibly as soon as midcentury, fisheries experts and ecologists are predicting. A21 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Lieberman's Failed '04 Run Hardened Independence Senator Joseph I. Lieberman's rejection by the Democratic Party in the waning days of his failed presidential run in 2004 played a role in his decision to run for re-election in Connecticut on his own party line, according to some friends and advisers. B1 High Stakes for Corzine Gov. Jon S. Corzine has worked behind the scenes to get his handpicked Democratic candidate, Robert Menendez, elected in the race for United States Senate in New Jersey. A defeat would be particularly stinging for Mr. Corzine, in part because a Democratic loss could cost the party control of the Senate. B1 BUSINESS DAY C1-10 Microsoft Links With Novell Microsoft acknowledged the influence of the Linux operating system by striking a deal with Novell, a longtime rival, to ensure that Novell's version of Linux can operate together with Windows in corporate data centers. C1 Business Digest C2 EDITORIAL A26-27 Editorials: Avoiding calamity on the cheap; fresh sorrows at ground zero; of red wine and fatty foods; Francis X. Clines on summoning Frederick Douglass. Columns: Paul Krugman, Thomas L. Friedman. OBITUARIES B8-9 Mose Tolliver A folk artist whose work made him one of the leaders of the modern-day Outsider Art movement, he was in his 80s. B8 Crossword E20 Public Lives B2 TV Listings E27 Weather D8
